text: Mrs. Robinson and the children in the taxi as they look o at the scene. (Stock shots of Pasadena's business section then of the residential area are to be inter-cut.)
As children leave school, trooping out noisily and happil Among the children are several Negroes.
The children and the mother gaze intently as they note Ne pupils among the white children. Then they gaze at each o as if it is something hard to believe.
As they turn their heads to continue looking at the schoo even though the taxi is now some distance past it.
As CAMERA FOLLOWS TAXI, we see that we are now in a low-p area of homes, stores, etc.

They had never seen anything like  the city that was to be their new  home. They looked and wondered and  the mother told herself that sooner  or later they would be well, if  humbly, settled there... And -- in  time -- they were... and very  humbly...
As narration fades, we
A nine year old colored boy is running towards the Robins home in high excitement. He is carrying a fielder's glove which he has to glance every other second though he is in full flight.

(talking through the  following scenes as  well) This isn't Jackie -- but when he was  nine, and the family couldn't afford  to get him a baseball glove, this is  how his mother helped him make a  necessary adjustment to life. Jackie  had found an old, dilapidated glove...
The kid leaps up the stairs and into the house.
The kid slides into the kitchen, holding the glove out to Mrs. Robinson who is turning around from the gas range, a talks to her eagerly.
She takes the glove, examines it, and has to smile. It is badly frayed, the side stitching burst in a number of pla and padding extruding. Nevertheless, she nods and turns  away...
Mrs. Robinson taking a sewing kit out of a drawer, the ki hopping around just in back of her and getting his head i her way. She goes to table, sits down, and commences thre a needle.
She starts to take the first stitch. He asks her somethin anxiously. She nods reassuringly and his face lights up w a heart-wide grin.
The same boy stands at a street corner, a bunch of newspa at his feet, a dozen or so more under his arm, selling pa both to car patrons and to pedestrians.
Between work and school Jackie, like  this boy, didn't have all the time  in the world to play...
The boy turns his back to camera as he sells a newspaper we see the glove sticking partially out of his back pocke
...but he always kept his glove  handy...
Running onto an empty lot where several other boys are pl ball in a make-shift game, is Jackie. One of the boys bat out a fly and Jackie scoots after it.

(NOTE: The following shots, illustrating narrator's talk, are quick, almost montage views, taken against any studio backgrounds already up and available. They are all angled keep face of boy unrecognizable... and as shots progress gets bigger to indicate his growth.)
Boy mopping a floor.
Boy delivering package to woman who opens door.
Boy piling up scrap lumber in corner of yard.
Boy pushing hand-truck loaded with sacks.
Boy driving small delivery truck, stopping and jumping ou with parcel.
(against above) All the things that boys find to do  when they have to work through their  schoolhood years, Jackie did...
Track events in progress. Students and fans watching.
...yet he managed to make time for  sports as well.
We get a bare flash of a young Negro lad in track suit ta his run and launching into a broad jump.

This still isn't Jackie, but when he  attended Pasadena Junior College he  led in all sports, broke the National  Junior College running broad jump  record with a leap of 25 feet, six  inches -- a record set a few years  earlier by his own brother, Mack!
Football game in progress, thousands of fans watching.

text: As signals are called and a runner gets the ball. (From t distance we can't recognize any player or distinguish act numbers on their uniforms.)
The player with the ball breaks through the opposing team line and dashes for the sidelines and toward camera.
But this -- IS -- Jackie Robinson...
As player nears camera we recognize him as Jackie. Over s is HEARD roar of the crowd. CAMERA HOLDS as Jackie runs i a CLOSE SHOT, then past camera.
...playing football for the University  of California at Los Angeles where  he had won an athletic scholarship.
Any shot of a player crossing into end zone for a touchdo as opposing players trail after him... this, apparently,  being the end of Jackie's run.
They are cheering.

These should be actual shots of Jackie in action against  various college teams during his UCLA days. (During these should work in a studio CLOSEUP or two to let us take a g look at the man.) Each of the shots is identified by the  narrator as follows:
Against Southern California!
Against Oregon!
Against Stanford! Etc.
We see small section of student body watching game. Seate with two white girl companions is an attractive Negro gir (Rae). After joining crowd in a cheer one of the white gi turns to Rae.
Jackie sure can run! How does it  feel to see your future husband going  wild down there?
(acting taken aback) Future husband? You're faster than  he is! He hasn't got that far yet.
(waving hand derisively) Now don't pretend, Rae! We know. (turning to other  white girl) Don't we, Claire?
As other nods --
So don't pretend, Rae!
Rae laughs but is a little embarrassed at being kidded ab it. The white girl sees this and pats Rae's face, as you  will to a child you are fond of, to indicate she meant no harm.
Another quick shot of action on the field, with crowd roa as we

Our shot takes in the tailgate of a furniture truck backe close to a warehouse-like entrance or loading platform. A tablet on wall of warehouse reading EMPIRE STORAGE COMPAN helps identify scene. A Negro of about fifty, strongly bu stands on truck tailgate waiting. Jackie, head hidden und huge club chair which he is carrying, walks into scene fr warehouse.
It wasn't all touchdowns and cheers,  however. There was also work...
Jackie swings chair to truck where older man grabs it.
(wiping perspiration) That's the last one, Jake.
Jake settles chair down, leans against it.
I saw you play yesterday.
(pleased) Yeah? Like the game?
(judiciously) It was good. You was good. But what's  the use if you got to do this kind  of work? I didn't have to go to no  college to get this job.
(smiling, after pause) You see, Jake, you're smarter than I  am.
Jake studies Jackie a moment, and then, with a slow, know smile, lifts chair up and disappears into truck with it.
General shot campus showing college buildings b.g. and  students either wandering around or lounging on ground.
And there was always studying to be  done.
Jackie sitting with back propped against tree reading boo
Oh, I'm sorry I'm late.
Jackie looks up as Rae enters scene. He would get up but slips down beside him before he can get started.
Stay put. I was held up by Claire  King. She just wanted to talk.
(indicating his book) That's okay. I can use all the time  I can get for this.
(pretending affront) Oh. Then I'll go.
Jackie instantly tosses book over one shoulder and takes of Rae's hands in his so she can't get away.
Did you say something?
(pretending alarm) Your book! What about your book?
What about you?
Rae has to break down and smile and they are looking at e other as we
Another game with stands loaded.
Rae and a few people around her.
A player, indistinguishable, goes down under tacklers.
Rae wincing as voices, o.s., yell:
Jackie's down! Wow! They sure got  him that time!
A white girl sitting with a boy friend in front of Rae  comments:
(indignantly) They sure pile on to him!
(brutally) What do you think? Who wouldn't if  they had a chance to slug...
The girl pokes him and indicates with her eyes that Rae i seated right behind them. The boy looks back at Rae, then his girl again with a non-committal shrug.
As the players finally unpile. However, the ball-carrier  lies there and two or three of his own teammates rush tow him.

Jackie on ground, ball under him, two or three players tr to help him to his feet. While they do so, the trainer ru into scene to help them. CAMERA HOLDS as the trainer and  another player help Jackie off the field. Over scene come cheer from the crowd, glad that Jackie isn't seriously hu However, he does have a decided limp.
She looks greatly relieved.
As they walk toward camera, then past camera, on their wa to dressing room, o.s.
As Jackie, the trainer and another player walk into scene and enter the dressing room. All are quiet, and over scen we HEAR roar of the fans again.

Lights are on, there is a doctor's bag on one of the rub- down tables, a dozen or so uniforms tossed on various cha and on the floor near the lockers. The trainer and player help Jackie up onto a table and pull his jersey off. Jack winces.
(talking as he works) Hurt much?
Yes.
Hip's badly bruised.
The player who helped Jackie off the field comes into sho He is angry.
I don't know what's wrong with those  guys giving it to Jackie like that.  Just because he's...
(curtly) Hold it! I knew before the game they  were out to watch Jackie close. The  trainer on their team told me. But  it was because of his playing ability  and nothing else.
Oh.
You better get back to the bench. (to Jackie) I wasn't kidding about that either,  Jackie. They had respect for you out  there. Plenty.
Jackie mulls over the trainer's words.
Thanks, Dick. It's nice to know.
(pleasantly) Say, Jackie. How's your brother Mack?  I remember him when he went to the  University of Oregon... and when he  ran in the Olympics overseas. One of  the finest athletes I ever met.
(after pause) Oh, Mack? He's fine. Fine, thank  you.

Jackie and Rae are sitting quietly on the steps. Mrs. Rob comes out door just as Jackie slips his body down one ste and lays his head against Rae's shoulder. Mrs. Robinson, has some knitting in her hand, goes to a chair in a dark  corner of the porch.
Still in some pain, aren't you? I  think football is a wild game. I  don't think I like it.
(shifting in discomfort) I don't myself right now.
I think it's disgusting... young men  battering each other... no better  than just plain old bulls.
Jackie gives Rae an amused side glance at this, then shru
Well, it won't last much longer.
Why? What are you going to do?
Oh... something. This isn't getting  me anywhere. I mean... this isn't  getting us anywhere.
He shifts about to look directly at Rae with a smile.
And that's serious!
(embarrassed) Oh-h!
She pushes his head around and away from her.
She sees this byplay and her face softens in a smile. Qui she gathers up her knitting and gets up.
Mrs. Robinson enters house. Jackie hears the door closing and looks around. Then he smiles down at Rae who smiles b in understanding.
She's cute.
Yeah...
What did you mean, Jackie? About  your going to do something?
(his face serious) Oh... I mean I'm too big to be just  ornamental... Keeps Mom and Mack  hustling to pay my way... I've got  to start in being real useful...

He is in bed, unable to sleep. He has a school book on a  table beside the bed; a small lamp is burning. He picks u the book and studies it for a few moments, but his heart  isn't in it. A clock on the table shows that it is three  o'clock in the morning. Jackie sighs deeply, then slowly  starts climbing out of bed, still careful of his hip.

Standing by the gas range Jackie pours hot coffee into a  vacuum lunch bottle. Two sandwiches are on a piece of pap He corks the bottle and is wrapping up the sandwiches whe we hear Mrs. Robinson's voice.
Who is that? You, Jackie?
Yes, mom.
(alarmed) You sick?
No. Just couldn't sleep. I'm going  out to see Mack. Want to talk to him  anyway.
Can't it wait till morning? It's  three o'clock.
I know. But I won't be long. I know  where to find him.
(fading off) Three o'clock! My! My! What a thing  to do... what a thing to do...

Jackie walking along Colorado Avenue, or similar business street, deserted and lonely at this hour except for a str cleaner in the distance. Jackie carries the lunch package one hand, much as he would a football. Sandwich and vacuu bottle are wrapped in the same, tight package.
Jackie approaching street cleaner who, however, does not  hear him because of the noise of his heavy broom and the  fact that parked cars separate the two men.

Jackie has reached car. He stops a second and we hear the street cleaner's broom being pushed over the concrete. Ja takes a few more steps, bringing him past the car. He sto and turns in the direction of the street cleaner.
(knowing it will be a  surprise) Hello, Mack.

We see that Mack, Jackie's older brother by three years, former University of Oregon track star, is the street cle He is in the loose uniform of the town's sanitation corps and is startled by Jackie's words and appearance, then gr
What the... what are you doing here  at this hour? Schoolboys should be  in bed.
Yeah. I couldn't sleep so I fixed  you some lunch. Here...!
He throws the package like a forward pass and Mack, shift broom to crook of his elbow, snags it expertly.
(dropping his broom) Man oh man -- I can use some... Hope  you figured I was a bit hungry...
He is obviously very pleased.
(chuckling) You bet. Coffee, too.
(indicating curb) Now you're talking. Let's sit down  and take it easy for a while...
Mack opens the package, takes a sandwich and offers one t Jackie. Jackie shakes his head.
(takes a bite) Anything bothering you?
Yeah. I want to quit college. Right  after the basketball season... when  my scholarship is up.
Mack almost chokes on his first bite.

(pounding Mack's back) Take it easy, boy. I don't want to  lose you now. (getting serious) You know Mom. She sees me as a doctor,  minister or lawyer, perhaps. I'd  like to please her but it just isn't  in me...
Yeah. I know.

(continuing his thought) It would mean years more in school --  and the way I feel, I'd rather work  at getting some kind of a sport job --  an assistant coach -- or a trainer --  something like that... But I can't  figure out which to aim at... Coaching  jobs are darn hard to get...

(thoughtfully) All I can say, Jackie, is that you  ought to stay in college as long as  you can -- try to graduate -- and  keep at sports as hard as you can.  Something might turn up... and as  far as education goes -- it'll do  you good...
Then, noticing the trash he has been sweeping, he smiles.
How much good -- I'm not saying.
Jackie nods. Neither of them is at all bitter about it. I is just accepted.
Sure... I know... But I've got to go  to work. I want to marry Rae. School's  one thing -- but you and Mom can't  support me in marriage.

During the scene, Mack has continued to eat and now he op the thermos of coffee. Jackie shakes his head that he doe want any and Mack pours himself a cup. As he starts to dr a convertible filled with young people drives in sight, t youngsters singing a football victory song. Jackie and Ma watch it drive by. Banners and streamers hang from the ca all showing UCLA insignia. Mack grins at Jackie.
Funny place for a football hero to  be sitting at this time of night...
Jackie grins back at him.
Funny job you've got for a university  man...
He kicks at the pile of debris near them. Mack grins back him, sighs.
(philosophically) That's the way it is...
They sit in silence for a moment and CAMERA PULLS BACK an draws away from them, their figures small against the lon lonely, dark street...
A student about to enter calls to another student passing by.
Hey, Jerry! Going to watch basketball  practice?
The passing student shakes his head and points to some bo he is carrying to indicate he has to study.
A practice session is on, the players just passing the ba around and shooting baskets. At the sidelines stands an  assistant coach.
We see him run to the basket, get the ball on a pass, and shoot. Catching the ball as it comes through the net he s it far upcourt.
(calling out) All right, fellows. Let's work out  in teams.
The players break up into two teams and take position for the start of a game.
Jackie and the player opposing him stand together waiting for the opening whistle to sound.
That true, Jackie, about your quitting  at the end of the basketball season?
As Jackie nods --
Not even going out for baseball again?
No, I'm not.
Don't you like baseball?
Can't afford to like it!
Why not?
Ever hear of a Negro in organized  ball?
We see a few seconds of game skirmish, and follow Jackie  down the court in a rush towards the basket which he  ultimately shoots.
They are both panting a little now as they line up agains each other again.
(smiling) Well, don't think I'll miss you.  I'll make the first team after you're  gone.
(with friendly dig  into player's ribs) Well, I'll miss you. You kept me  stepping.
The other player pulls his fist back as if to sock Jackie
Get out! Kept you stepping! I didn't  have a chance!
They are both grinning as the whistle sounds and they jum into play again.

We see Jackie in action against other college teams durin the basketball season, and over each separate game appear title identifying the particular rival college involved i the shot. After final shot we
A group of students on the steps of one of the campus  buildings are reading the college paper which is held by of them.
One of the students is reading aloud.
"UCLA loses four-letter athlete.  Jackie Robinson leaving school."
He wasn't kidding.
Gee, that boy's gonna leave a hole  behind him hard to fill. How come?
One of the other students rubs forefinger against thumb i the "money sign."
Economics, my boy. A man must live  before he can play. And in order to  live...
He makes the money sign again as we cut go:
Jackie is taking his stuff from his locker and packing it a small bag. The trainer we met in the football sequences and a student are standing by. Jackie is explaining somet to them.
...Coming out of Junior College to  UCLA, the way I did, I only had a  two-year scholarship to fit my  athletic eligibility. Well... the  scholarship is over.
Isn't there any way you can stay on?
My mother is 63 years old. She's  worked as housekeeper, maid, cook,  laundress, janitress and selling  yard goods in a store to keep us  kids going.
She wanted to do it. She must not  want to see you give up now.
Yes, she'd work for the next ten  years if I stayed in school...
Well?
Can't take a chance. I can't expect  more future than Mack... and with  all his college he wasn't able to  get anything worth while. That's not  worth ten more years of work for my  mother.
His packing finished, Jackie shakes hands with both men.
Luck to you, and I'll take the same.
(ad lib) All the luck in the world. You'll  make out all right, Jackie.
As Jackie exits the trainer turns to the student.

Somehow it doesn't make sense. The  only four-letter man we've had at  UCLA in ten years. High basketball  scorer for us in both years he was  here. On top of that he's as fine a  baseball player as I have ever seen...  and it don't mean a thing. He's  walking out of here without anything  ahead of him except a couple of games  of pro-football signed up.
Maybe he can have a career in  professional football.
(shaking his head) Baseball is his game.
He tells everyone he doesn't care  about baseball.
(with a short smile) Yeah... I know. What else is he going  to say?

A pair of hands counting a roll of paper money, each bill being slapped down on a table. CAMERA MOVES BACK to reveal Jackie standing up and counti the money in front of his mother who is seated at the tab She seems puzzled as she looks at the bills and then up a him.
What's that, Jackie?
(still counting) Money. Remember, Mom?
She gives him a warning glance not to joke with her.
What is that, Jackie?
(in mollifying tone) Okay. Okay, Mom. It's an advance  payment for playing professional  football. I'm signed up to play for  Honolulu.
He tidies up the bills and leaves them in front of her as sits down.
But I don't like for you to play  football. Is that why you quit  college?
No, Mom. I'm going there just to  play a few games. They came to me  when they heard I was going to quit.  We can use the money till I get what  I want. So I took it.
Honolulu's far away.
I'll be there and back inside of two  months.
She is troubled as she looks at the money and then up at  Jackie again. He shrugs.
And then, maybe, I'll have some  answers to all the letters I've been  writing for a coaching job.
When she still doesn't reply he smiles and reaches out to pat her folded hands reassuringly.
It'll be all right, Mom. Just give  me a little time and you'll be proud  of me.
She looks directly at him.
I was proud of you when you went to  college.
(gravely) I know. But... I didn't feel proud  of myself.
Jackie and Rae are sitting on the front steps, apparently having reached a pause in their conversation which has le them both looking a little troubled.
CAMERA MOVES IN as we hear:
...May take us a little longer this  way but it means a better start...
As she nods mechanically --
When it does... uh... (in sudden disgust) Oh... maybe you're right. Maybe I'm  just going around in circles.
Rae turns to him quickly in sudden compunction.
Jackie, I'm sorry. I didn't mean to  act so cold to the idea. I'm not  even listening because... because I  just don't want you to go away.
As he tries to talk --
No. I know you have to do something  like this to get a start. I know...  but that doesn't make me like it.
(taking her hand) All right. And I am going around in  circles. I don't know how to beat  that. But Rae... there's one thing I  want you to be sure of...
As she nods --
Every circle comes right back to  you.
As her face lights up --
And all I'm worrying about is getting  around fast enough!
They smile at each other and then Rae leans her head back against Jackie's chest. They stay like this, both gazing  off, when she speaks again.
(slowly) I have to take my post-graduate  nursing course in a hospital. I think  I can get in Bellevue in New York.  That's where I'll be...
(frowning) But why so far...
(turning to face him) That's where I'll be when you're  ready. It's better that way. Something  for me to do. You're more free...
They study each other's faces.
All right.

A corner of a cabin. Jackie is typing away at a small tab next to a porthole through which we can see a mid-ocean  horizon rising and falling with the roll of the ship. Nex to him is a small pile of letters already written. The di clang of ship's bells is HEARD.

We can see that the letter is printed "S.S. LURLINE - HON BOUND." Under it he has typed the following heading and  salutation: "Mr. W.J. Jeffrey Athletic Director Overton College Overt Calif." And that he is tapping out the first few lines of his let which begins as follows: "Dear Mr. Jeffrey: In application for an athletic coaching, or assistant  coaching, appointment at Overton, I would like to submit following qualifications..."
Opening with STOCK of Hawaii, then into clips of several  football games, ending with a SHOT of a steamship leaving Hawaii.
He is walking up to the house, carrying a suitcase in eac hand. CAMERA HOLDS as he reaches front door.
He lowers suitcases and knocks at the door as he finds it locked. He waits a moment, gets no answer, then finds his own key and unlocks the door.
As Jackie enters, places his bags on the floor and closes the door behind him. He stands there for a moment, then g toward a table where there are several pieces of mail.

He picks up the dozen or so letters and finds that four o them are for him. He sits down, opens and reads them, one one. We do not see the first two which he crumples up and drops into a wastebasket. The third one he re-reads and t about for a moment, then places it to one side. The fourt he reads and crumples again and discards with the others. Then he rises and walks back and forth as he thinks. Afte moment he stands at the living room window and stares out silently.
He stares out of the window, then sees something, turns a heads for the front door.
Mrs. Robinson is walking up toward the house, carrying tw large sacks of groceries. Jackie hurries to meet her, gre her and taking the packages at the same time, even as the embrace.
Hello, Mom...
(happy to see him) I was hoping you'd be here -- your  telegram came just a little while  ago so I went out to get some  things...
He knows that she intended to get some extra-special food for a homecoming dinner. CAMERA PANS them into the house.
Jackie and his mother enter and pass through into the kit
(as they walk through) ...you didn't get hurt, did you?
As they enter kitchen to put down the packages.
(as he enters) Not a scratch. Got a sore arm though --  from writing letters...
(as she follows him  in) Letters? Some letters came for you.
She comes back into the living room, heads for the table  where Jackie picked up his mail. As Jackie reenters:
I put them here...
I read them...
She turns to him, hoping that he will have some good news He smiles at her, then moves over and picks up the letter saved and hands it to her.
As she reads the letter.
(thoughtfully) What's this National Youth  Association...?
It's something the Government set up  to help underprivileged children ---  they get all sorts of training ---
(hopefully) ...And they want you to be an athletic  instructor?
Looks that way... Anyway, I'm taking  it before they change their minds...
Mrs. Robinson looks at the letter again, then back at Jac
...Pennsylvania... (with a smile) You'll be near Rae, anyway...
She moves to the sofa and sits down as she talks.
Maybe you can be there when she  graduates -- or whatever it is --  from the hospital...
(nodding) Yeah. (joshing her) So even if we don't have a doctor in  the family, we'll have a registered  nurse, anyway... (reflectively) ...I hope...
Why not write her and let her know...?
(nodding) Good idea. Soon's I put my stuff  up...
He turns, picks up his suitcases and starts through the h door with them and we

This is a room in the nurses' quarters of a large hospita Everything white, clean, uncrowded. Rae, in graduate nurs uniform, is seated at a desk reading a letter. On the des is a picture of Jackie -- in civilian clothes. There is a box of stationery, ink, pen, etc., on the table in additi to several books.
She shakes her head, smiling a bit, but with a bit of sad
"...I'm enjoying my work with the kids and the Associatio has been fine to me. I'll be leaving it soon, though, as Army has called. But at least, I can stop worrying about future for awhile..."
Rae folds the letter and smiles in sad contemplation as w hear her thinking voice paraphrase Jackie's last sentence
He can stop worrying now that he's  in the Army...
We know that she will really start worrying. She glances the framed photograph of him. As we look at it, Jackie's  clothes change into the uniform of an Army Private.
If obtainable we will show quick scenes of Jackie's army  life as he supervises various athletic activities.

There is a picture of Jackie in the uniform of an Army  private. The uniform fades and is replaced by the uniform a first lieutenant. CAMERA PULLS BACK from photograph and we see that Rae is  writing a letter.
"...so I will be finished with my course in two weeks and then go back home. When you get your Army discharge I'll waiting for you in California..."
This is supposed to be Ft. Breckenridge, Kentucky, althou it can be any large Army installation as long as it remai unidentifiable.
Marching, training, etc.
Entering and leaving barracks, etc.

He is packing a suitcase and an Army bag. CAMERA PULLS BACK to reveal another Negro officer with Ja This man sits on a bunk -- both are dressed in their unif Jackie moves to a chest and takes some clothes and stuffs them into the Army bag. Then he takes a photo of Rae off wall and packs that in the suitcase. The last thing he re from the chest is a fielder's baseball glove.
What you going to do with that?
(studying glove) I don't know. Don't know if I'll  ever do anything with it again...
INSERT JACKIE'S HANDS stuffing glove into his bag.

As Jackie's reaches into it and comes out with the glove. There is a burst of laughter as CAMERA PULLS BACK to show that Jackie is home and unpacking his bag in front of Rae Mrs. Robinson and Mack, all three of whom are laughing.
Just like you. First thing one sees  when you unpack is a baseball glove...  or a pair of spiked shoes...
Jackie draws himself up a little stiffish and addresses R in formal tones.
And when have you ever seen me unpack  before, Miss Isum?
(embarrassed in front  of Mrs. Robinson and  Mack) I didn't mean that I had ever seen  you... why, Jackie! What do you... (whirling about) Well, if that's to be your attitude!
She flounces from room and Jackie motions to his mother a Mack as he prepares to follow.
Excuse me. I have to effect a...  a... a rapprochement, I think they  call it.
He hurries after Rae while Mrs. Robinson looks after him then turns to Mack to ask with suspicion edging her voice
What's he mean by that... that  rapproche -- that stuff?
(shaking head) Search me. We didn't bother with  that kind of stuff when I went to  college.
Same scene as Scene 43. Jake is standing on back of truck maneuvering a settee onto its legs when Jackie walks into the scene and smiles up at him.
H'ya, Jake.
You been out of the Army a long time  now, Jackie. Ain't got yourself a  good coaching job yet?
Not quite.
(grunting) Still writing letters, eh?
Yes. But if I don't get an answer  soon I'll be back here looking for  my old job.
I hope that don't happen, son. But  if it does... I can sure use you. (changing tone) Why don't you go to them coaching  places in person instead of writing  them letters?
You mean why don't I spend fifty  dollars train fare instead of a three  cent stamp?
(laughing) Yeah... I ain't got all the brains  in the world. (laughing louder) I wouldn't even want to prove I got  my share!
The two are laughing, with Jake sounding off in wild whoo when Mack's voice is heard, o.s.
(calling) Jackie!
They stop laughing and turn around as Mack runs into scen carrying a letter which he hands to Jackie.
(excited) It just came.
Jackie tears letter open.
He is reading letter.
(to Jake) It's from the Kansas City Monarchs.  It can only be one thing... an offer.
Who are they?
(surprised) Never heard of the Kansas City  Monarchs? It's a professional baseball  team.
But I thought professional teams  don't want us.
It's an all-colored team.
Jackie looks up and Mack can't wait.
Well?
(a little dazed) A hundred dollars a week... to play  shortstop.
Jake jumps from truck and is so intrigued he takes letter from Jackie to puzzle over it himself.
(puzzled) And I didn't even write them. How  did they know?
Oh, they knew about you from UCLA  and some of the pro games you played  at Brookside. They must have scouted  you.

(handing letter back  to Jackie) Here. That's what it says... a hundred  a week. (studying furniture  on truck) Just pushing a little old baseball  around. Maybe there's something to  that college stuff after all.
Just a table in a corner at which sit Jackie and Rae, the latter in white uniform of a nurse, and with Coca Cola bo and glasses before them. An air of sadness seems to have  overcome both of them.
(thoughtfully) Well... you've got to take it. I  don't see what else you can do.

(in same mood) Yeah... and if I can stay with the  Monarchs a couple of years I should  be able to save up a little money. (looking at her) Maybe even enough... (hopefully) Maybe when I know I'm set there,  then...?
She nods, but not with any particular enthusiasm. Jackie  notes this and nods slowly in agreement with her reaction
I don't blame you. Gee... a couple  more years. Why don't we set a wedding  date for about 1960 and have it over  with?
Rae doesn't think it is funny, even if it wasn't meant to be. She stands up and looks at her wristwatch.
I don't know about 1960, but in five  minutes I'm due back in the ward.
Jackie gets up and puts some coins on the table.
And tomorrow I'm due in Kansas City.
They stand looking at each other, both with blank faces,  unable to fathom either how to solve their problem or wha lies ahead of this new development as we

o.s., we HEAR crowd noises.
The playing field. A game is in progress.
A fair-sized audience, practically all colored.
Jackie, in uniform, is sitting in a corner of dugout alon an older man, apparently the manager.
This being your first game I was  going to hold you out a couple of  innings but maybe you want to take a  lick at bat now? (nodding to batter) Follow Joe.
(rising) Okay.
As Jackie starts away --
And look! Uh... we give them a show  out there, Jackie. If you make an  out, act mad. If you think you get a  bad call on a ball, talk it up. They  like that here.
Jackie considers this, nods, and then walks away quietly. The manager shakes his head as if doubtful that Jackie ca come through on this order.
Jackie, bat in hand, moves "on deck" and squats, waiting turn.
A Monarch player waggling bat viciously as if daring pitc to throw one in the groove.
Holding a "two-three" count up with his fingers.
Gazing contemptuously towards batter, winding up and thro
Striking out with a tremendous swing, he yells in fury an starts pounding the ground with his bat in anger.
As Jackie moves to plate he passes the retired batter. Th latter is still gesticulating angrily, but as he passes J he winks at him and we know it is all an act for the fans
As loudspeaker announcement is heard:
Now batting for Kansas City Monarchs  in place of Rumley -- Jackie Robinson!
Jackie takes his stance. The catcher squats and begins ta it up.
(calling to pitcher) This is a new boy, Bill. Take it  real easy with him. Don't discourage  the new boy. Nice and easy! Nice and  easy!
As the catcher is talking Jackie turns and nods to him as grateful for the expected gentle treatment.

He acts interested in what catcher is telling him, then n as if in gentlemanly agreement with the policy of treatin new man with consideration. He begins his windup slowly b when he finally whips the ball it is with everything he's got.

The ball streaks past Jackie's head so closely that he ha to fall to ground to avoid getting beaned. As he gets up, acting fully bewildered, the catcher runs to him and help him dust his clothes, simulating deep concern. Jackie gaz at catcher, and then at pitcher, with great suspicion.
The spectators are enjoying this byplay hugely.
Jackie waiting and showing determination to hit. He swing and hits... but doesn't run.
The ball going high over the stands and onto the roof.

Jackie swings and misses, so hard that he is carried seve feet from plate and ends up facing stands. He acts angry, pulls his bat back of him with one hand and looks as if h is going to sling it into the seats. For a moment he stands thus, wrestling with himself almos as if trying to control his temper. There is a roar of  excitement from the spectators, and then Jackie lets the down. Lowering his head in deep dejection he starts walki back to the dugout. The crowd's yelling now turns to laug
As Jackie steps in to resume his seat next to manager.
(enthusiastic) That was great, Jackie! Fine stuff!  They loved it.
As Jackie nods --
But, of course, you know...
As Jackie looks up --
You're also supposed to get a hit  once in a while
He casts an amused look at manager from under his eyebrow
Make up your mind.

The Monarch batter hits a pop fly and the side is retired The Monarch team, including Jackie who goes to shortstop, takes the field. The infielders snap up ground balls thro by first base and we get our first glimpse of Jackie in a as a fielder.

Various shots of Jackie in action as a shortstop; picking a ground ball and shooting it to first, covering second a throwing to first for a double play, backing up the third baseman on a hot grounder and recovering when the latter  boots one.
A series of ciphers show three innings have been played. the fourth inning slot the figure "1" appears for each te and then further ciphers appear up to the beginning of th ninth inning.
The Monarchs come running in, including Jackie who goes t the bat rack.
He selects a bat and heads for the plate.
Jackie first takes a strike, then cuts at the next pitch lines a double into the field. The crowd yells.
As Jackie runs, then slides into second just in time to b the pitch from the outfield. He gets up and dusts himself off as the second baseman, ball in hand, grins at him.
About time you started hitting, boy.

Jackie grins and the second baseman returns the ball to t pitcher. As he throws, Jackie suddenly lights out for thi and catches the pitcher flatfooted, not expecting such a  daring play. The crowd roars as Jackie slides safely into third.
Looking disgusted with himself.
Grinning to himself. He obviously loves the sport and enj a spectacular play. He takes a long lead, teasing the pit

The next batter flies to the infield and Jackie gets back base in time. The shortstop holds the ball for a moment,  then satisfied that Jackie is holding the bag, tosses to pitcher. The moment the ball leaves his hand, Jackie has  started for home. By the time the pitcher catches the bal and relays it to the catcher, Jackie is sliding in safe a home plate. The crowd roars approval of his daring base- running.
As Jackie returns. Several players grin and ad lib their  approval of the way he has handled himself. As the game  continues, one of the players, Slim, moves close to Jacki and starts a conversation.
Good going. You ought to sleep well  tonight.
I generally sleep pretty good.
On a bus?
(thoughtfully) That's right. I forgot we travel by  bus.
Make four hundred mile jumps between  games. Only chance we ever get to  hit a bed is in a two or three game  series.
Not so good.
It ain't de luxe, brother!

This is designed to show the nomadic life of these  ballplayers. A. Players piling into their own bus at night. B. Players inside bus, half asleep as they travel. C. Shots of game, including Jackie getting a hit. D. Bus traveling again. E. Players dressing on bus, getting into their uniforms. F. Players emerging from bus at ballpark, going right ont field as if they've delayed game by late arrival. G. Inside bus again; night, players asleep, some still in uniform. H. Game in progress. Jackie in good fielding play. I. Shot of fans showing their appreciation of game.

As it drives past. Through the windows we get a glimpse o the players.
In the dim illumination we can see the players, a few asl most sprawled out and listening to a major league night g broadcast.
Slim has a portable radio on his lap. Jackie is in seat b him.
It's two and two on Greenberg as  Feller winds up... and it's ball  three...

head_text.subj: HIGH-PITCHED WAIL FROM REAR OF BUS

text: Shut off that radio! I want to sleep.
Quiet, Leander! That's Hank Greenberg  at bat. (to Jackie) That Leander! He sleeps all day out  in right field.
I don't care if it's Duke Ellington!  I want to sleep.
(to radio) Come on, Hank. Wait it out... 'less  it's good.
There's the windup again... and  Greenberg SWINGS at a high one and  he's out!
There is a general murmur of disgust from all in the bus.
(provoked) What he bite on that for? (snapping off radio) Ah-h... that's the game!
There is a lull as everyone settles back with closed eyes Then the plaintive voice of Leander is heard again.
Hey-y-y!
(angrily) What you want now, Leander? I turned  the radio off. Go to sleep.
I ain't sleepy no more. I'm hungry.
Several players open up their eyes and consider this. The look at each other and seem to indicate Leander has somet
The bus driver looks back and then at the manager who occ a front seat.
Hungry? Why you... (on second thought) Hungry... (looking back at Jackie) How about you?
Jackie compresses his lips and nods as if it isn't a bad  idea at all. Almost immediately other players pick up  Leander's word and we hear them.
(ad lib) Yeah... hungry. I can eat. About  time... gotta get out of here anyway.  I'm for it!
He checks manager who nods in agreement. Driver nods back and peers ahead.

location: OVER DRIVER'S SHOULDER AND THROUGH B

text: We see a forlorn-looking combination filling station and  lunch room, with several cars parked around.
(over shoulder) Don't look too bad...
As the players, full of good humor, move around in their  seats, trying to see the lunch room.
As the bus pulls in and to a stop.
The players, Jackie included, peering through the bus win studying the almost deserted roadside cafe.
(at them all) Whose turn? Let's not waste time...
The players look at each other and finally Slim gets to h feet. He combs his hair and brushes at his clothes, tryin to look as presentable as possible. The others watch him he leaves the bus.
Slim starts toward the cafe. He hesitates at the door for moment, then enters.

A plain eating spot with one long counter, usual coffee u and wall aperture through which the chef can be seen in t kitchen. Three male patrons are seated together halfway d from the door, and the counterman, about thirty, is leani against the wall talking to them as Slim enters. The four look towards Slim without any welcome and wait till he  approaches.
(nodding) Sixteen of us... in the bus outside.  How's chances of getting a late  dinner?
The patrons look to the counterman to see what his reply  will be. He notes their stare and then folds his arms.
I'm all alone here. Afraid I couldn't  handle you.
The three patrons now swing their stare on Slim.
He seems not surprised and is ready with his next questio
How about sandwiches? Could you have  the chef make some up for us?
He seems to be considering this but before he can answer offstage voice is heard:
How many of you?
The chef, a rugged, elderly fellow is looking through the window.
Sixteen.
Make you about sixteen beefs, sixteen  ham and eggs. That be all right?
Slim walks to chef as he replies.
Swell. Some fried potatoes on the  side, chef?
(disappearing) Yup. (o.s.) Take about twenty minutes.
The counterman walks into scene and stoops under counter get a roll of paper containers.
(a bit sulky) Coffee for everybody?
Yeah... but don't pour it until the  sandwiches are ready, please... so  the coffee will be hot.
Just getting it ready, Bud. Just  getting it ready.
Thanks.
He indicates outside with his thumb.
You suppose we could wash up a bit?
The counterman sneaks a quick look towards window but the chef is apparently too busy to hear this. He turns back t Slim.
Sorry. It's out of order.
His face is expressionless.
Oh... Thanks. Then we'll go up the  road and be back in fifteen minutes.
Have to leave a deposit on the  sandwiches in that case.
(reaching into pocket) Sure.
Slim leaves lunch room and walks slowly to bus.
Shooting towards front entrance as Slim climbs aboard.
They're feeding us. That's all. I  told them we're goin' up the line a  bit.
Without another word the driver starts the motor up.
The bus starts up the highway.
We see the bus coming to a stop alongside a wooded sectio The door opens and the players straggle out. One by one t disappear from sight as they walk into the woods and bush as we
The bus speeding along.
Now everyone but the driver is asleep, stretched out in t various and often grotesque postures typical of bus slumb
Any sort of corridor in which Rae, in hospital uniform, m another colored nurse. Rae carries medical tray.
'Morning, Rae. I read about your  Jackie last night. He's been going  great for months. He write you?
Yes. He's doing well. Except he  doesn't like the traveling.
Well, tell him to give it up and  come back here and get a job.
(with slight smile) I sure feel like it.
That's the time to write.
(shaking head) I'll wait. Waited this long.
They smile and pass on.
TOWARD BOX OFFICE. A sign visible: "MONARCHS vs. CHICAGO"
A fair-sized crowd, players warming up on the field, but game hasn't started.

Several players stand near the dugout, throwing balls bac and forth. Taking it easy as they warm up. Since most of  them are watching those players on the field, we realize  that the Chicago players are those practicing; the Monarc are waiting for their turn.
Jackie and Slim enter the dugout from clubroom runway and notice Bill Piedmont, a pitcher, sitting alone, somewhat  disconsolately. Jackie and Slim settle down on each side Bill.
What's the matter with you? Didn't  you pitch and win yesterday?
That's right. You were hot.
Yeah... but there's no future to it.
What'ya mean?
(to Jackie) How much does a twenty game win  pitcher get paid in the major league?
I don't know. Thirty thousand up,  maybe.
That's right. And I've won thirty so  far... and I'll get more.
And you ain't getting any thirty  thousand.
(staring at Slim) Funny boy.
Think you could do as well in the  majors?
No. Not any thirty or more. But I'd  sure come close to twenty...
I think so.
(getting up) And maybe be able to save a few  dollars for when my arm goes...
He walks off. Slim watches him and turns to Jackie.
He's right. We're all in the same  boat. Get enough to get by -- but  nothing to put by.
Slim gets up.
Well...
He doesn't finish but walks out on field leaving Jackie a Jackie sits thinking and we can hear Slim's words echoing his mind...
(echo box) ...enough to get by -- but nothing  to put by...
Someone calls Jackie and he snaps out of his reverie and  runs onto field.
Centering on Jackie at shortstop as play begins. We HEAR crack of a bat and Jackie shoots over to his left to make pickup and throw out to first. It is a neat, fast play.
Jackie stepping up to bat.
We see him talking into his mike.
Jackie Robinson up again. He got a  hit once and walked once. Let's see  what he does now.
The ball flashes by Jackie, low. He makes no move.
Ball one. Too low.
Jackie waggling his bat, drawing it back... but failing t swing as the ball comes by low again.
Ball two!
He is plainly nettled as he receives ball, gets catcher's sign, and winds up.
From behind catcher. We see Jackie poised to hit, the bal coming... and Jackie merely lifts his elbows to let ball  come through.
Ball!
He is laughing.
Jackie is not biting. They've got  the wrong man. It's ball three now  and the pitcher's on the spot.
He wipes sweat from brow. Winds up and --
The ball comes by and without waiting for the umpire's ca Jackie tosses his bat aside and makes for first.
Laughing again.
Ball four and Jackie walks again.  He's got eyes, that boy.

With the first baseman in the act of tossing the ball bac to the pitcher -- the ball still in mid-air -- Jackie is on a dash to second. The pitcher is rattled, fumbles  momentarily, and then gets off a high throw. Jackie is sa on a long, hooked slide.
Monarch players are tumbling into the dugout from the fie ad libbing about winning a tough game.
We see Jackie loping along towards dugout. Suddenly his n is called and he looks towards the boxes.
Oh, Robinson! Can I see you a minute?
Jackie pauses, then veers toward the box seats.
Sukeforth is standing as Jackie enters the scene. Sukefor extends his hand and Jackie takes it... wondering and per a little suspicious that he may be dealing with a crank.
My name is Clyde Sukeforth. I'm with  Branch Rickey... of the Brooklyn  Dodgers...
Jackie neither changes expression nor acknowledges this i any way. Sukeforth climbs out of box onto field and takes Jackie's arm.
I'll walk up to the dressing room  with you. Talk to you there.
They start off, Jackie still wondering.
Stopping outside the dressing room door, Sukeforth begins talking again. Several Monarch players, including Slim, w by and look at them curiously.
Branch Rickey wants to see you.
What for?
Frankly, I don't know. Can you leave  for Brooklyn tonight with me?
Jackie is taken aback by this, then, after studying Sukef he suddenly nods his head.
Sure.
(pleased) Great! I'm at the Palmer House. I'll  arrange for our railroad tickets and  suppose you phone me at the Palmer  at seven?
I'll do that, Mr. Sukeforth.
They shake hands and Sukeforth leaves. Jackie stands look after him a moment, his head shaking in wonder. Then he e dressing room.
Jackie reaches his locker and starts pulling his shirt of Slim enters scene accompanied by Bill, the pitcher.
Who was that white man, Jackie? A  friend of yours?
Nope. Said he was a scout for the  Brooklyn Dodgers. Said Branch Rickey  wants to see me.
(nudging Bill) S'matter? You owe Rickey some money  or something?
Yeah... what does Mr. Rickey want to  see you about?
(smiling) He didn't say. Just wants to see me.  Maybe to see if I've got two heads  or something.
What'd you say?
He's getting the train tickets and  I'm to phone him at seven at his  hotel.
Better hurry up and pack. We'll miss  you.
(laughing) You don't think I'm crazy, do you?
Slim and Bill join in the laughter and Bill lets his hand fall on Jackie's shoulders.
You'll find a lot of these cranks  showing up. I don't know what makes  'em do it. Last year I was signed to  pitch for the Giants, Senators and  Cincinnati.
But none of us have ever been signed  for Brooklyn yet. That's a new one.  You ought to take Bill and me out  and show us a good time on the  strength of that.
On the strength of that I'm going to  have dinner and go home to bed. It's  been four days since we had a bed to  sleep in and I'm going to get a  nightful of it.
You got something there...
He is in bed, sound asleep, when a knock is heard at the  door. Jackie rolls over a bit, paying no attention.
As he lifts his head sleepily when the knocking continues louder this time.
Who is it?
There is silence for a moment, then a dry, angry voice is heard.
Robinson? Clyde Sukeforth.

He appears stunned, is completely motionless for a moment then snaps on the bedside lamp. The room is illuminated f the first time and we see that it is a cheap one, poorly  furnished. On the dresser is a framed picture of Rae.
(fully awake) Just a second!
He gets out of bed, in his pajamas, and hurries to open t door. From his expression he still isn't sure what to exp
As Jackie opens it and an annoyed-looking Sukeforth enter They stare at each other for a moment.
(angrily) What are you trying to pull, Robinson?
He moves into the room, angrily continuing to berate Jack
Playing hard to get or something...?  Or just trying to make a fool out of  me? Acting like a smart guy... making  me miss my train... (disgusted) I should have taken it and not come  here...
He is growing indignant at this treatment from a man he i not sure of. He controls his temper, but nevertheless mak himself plain.
Just a minute, Mr. Sukeforth -- if  that's your name... I don't know you  and you don't know me...
Sukeforth looks at him sharply. Jackie hesitates, then  continues.
...If Mr. Rickey did send you to see  me, then I've made a big mistake --  and I'm sorry...
Sukeforth doesn't understand for a moment. Then, angrily, reaches into his pocket, brings out his wallet and gives  Jackie a card.
Jackie looks up from the card, puzzled.
It's still hard to believe... A lot  of fellows come to the game and...  you know.
(getting Jackie's  reasoning) Oh... You thought I was giving you  the business! I should have thought  of that...
Jackie relaxes a bit and waits for Sukeforth to continue.
(smiling) When Mr. Rickey told me to come out  here and talk to you, I didn't think  I was hearing right myself... but  here I am...
He looks around the room, then back to Jackie.
And you said you don't know why he  wants to see me.
(no longer angry) I don't... (thoughtfully) Unless...
(urging him on) After all, there's no chance for me  in major league baseball.
As Sukeforth nods in agreement --
So... what...
The only thing I can think of... and  I've got no right to suggest it...  just between us...
Yes?
There's talk about an all-Negro  football team being started by Mr.  Rickey... the Brown Dodgers...
Oh... so that's it. Football.
I don't know. But he wants to see  you and he's paying your fare...  both ways if you come back... What  do you say... yes or no?
Jackie looks around the room, plainly at a loss.
You'll just have to make up your  mind, quick. I can't tell you any  more. I don't know any more.
I... Okay.
Fine. Let's pack. We leave in an  hour.
A game is on.
Jackie and Sukeforth round a corner and walk down the hal toward camera. CAMERA PULLS BACK and PANS to a doorway on which is printed:
Branch Rickey, President.
CAMERA HOLDS as Jackie and Sukeforth walk up to the door. Sukeforth opens it without knocking and leads Jackie insi
An attractive secretary sits at a desk. Two doors lead in adjoining offices. On the walls are signed, framed photog of some of the old and new Dodgers.
Hello, Mr. Sukeforth... Mr. Rickey  is expecting you.
Sukeforth leads the way to a door marked "MR. RICKEY." He opens it and motions Jackie to step in first.
On Rickey, as he looks up towards camera from his desk in good-sized, well-furnished office, decorated with additio pictures of baseball notables -- officials as well as pla
(heartily) Hello, Clyde! Got your man, eh?
He stands up, warm of face and manner, but we can tell fr the look in his eyes that he is making a quick and keen s of Jackie.
Come in, Jackie. I'm very glad to  see you.
As Sukeforth and Jackie come up to desk.
How do you do, Mr. Rickey.
Yes, this is Jackie Robinson... and  it looked for a while as if I wasn't  going to get him here.
(to Jackie) Sit down, won't you? (to Sukeforth) Oh, no? (to Jackie) How come? Don't like Brooklyn?
As he takes a chair.
I've got nothing against Brooklyn.  But... uh... on the Monarchs we get  all kinds of men who show up and  talk big about signing us up for  this and that. It's a kind of a gag.
Oh, sure! Sure! Sure! But didn't  Clyde show you his credentials?
Yes... we got together finally.
Well, that's the main thing... And  now...
Yes, sir?
You're wondering, naturally, why I  sent for you.
More than wondering, Mr. Rickey. I'm  most curious. Although... I sort of  figured it out for myself...
(a bit surprised) You did?
Well, I know you're starting an all- colored football team.
Oh! Yes! Yes! We are thinking about  that. But... that's not what I want  you for. (quietly; after pause) Jackie, I want you for baseball.
Jackie is bewildered. He looks towards Sukeforth as if fo help in understanding but Sukeforth's expression is just puzzled. Then Jackie turns back and his face hardens a bi
You said that as if you were talking  about organized baseball, Mr. Rickey.  But I'm a Negro. There are none of  us in big league ball. I don't  understand...
Why I should want to put a Negro  into baseball?
Yes.
(nodding) I'm going to tell you... (to Sukeforth) And you, Clyde. (looking off) Because I am going to have to tell  many people.
Jackie and Sukeforth consult each other with another glan as Rickey falls silent a moment.
Leaning forward to Jackie.

I have been looking for someone like  you -- an intelligent, educated,  good Negro ballplayer -- for some  time. I needed a man whose character  was well regarded and whose background  was unblemished. As far as we can  find out, you are such a man. You  might as well know now... we've done  a lot of checking up on you. I can  tell you your life story from Georgia  to where you are sitting now. It may  be that you will be the first Negro  in organized baseball.

He is flabbergasted and, at the same time, beginning to f an excitement which he cannot well hide. But he is also  puzzled, and his hand goes to his chest, indicating himse as he manages to get out one word...
But...
As Rickey stands up and shoots a finger out at Jackie as guessing what is on his mind.

Why you? Let's get this straight so  we can all understand it. It's too  important for anyone to have a false  impression. People are going to shoot  at us... we must know where we stand.  I didn't call you here because I  want to do something for you, or for  your race, or for the Brooklyn Ball  Club. I want to do something for all  of us... All of us Americans.
Rickey turns and gazes out of the window.
The park is crowded with fans. (The Brooklyn Ball Club of are not near Ebbetts Field; they are in downtown Brooklyn But the liberty we take is not offensive and should not b objectionable to anyone.)
...For years I have seen and watched  Americans together in the grandstands  and bleachers of our country's ball  parks... Negroes, whites of all  nationalities...

Selected to illustrate Rickey's continued speech. (Great  care should be taken here as the proper scenes can lend  pointed and heartwarming emphasis to this important, key  scene. We see Negroes and Whites laughing together, growi tense together, gulping with relief as some emergency is  met. We may have a group CLOSEUP which might include (thi may have to be staged) an American executive type, a Negr and a Jew, suddenly all filled with heartbreak or dismay a hometown hero has apparently struck out, or some other break has ensued. In no case need we show what they are  watching. The faces of the crowds can express the typical emotional situations that come up in any game.)

...Italians, Irish, Swedes, Jews,  Germans, Chinese, Russians, Japanese,  Czechs... and I have marveled at  their fellowship, their cheers,  laughter, disappointments, enthusiasm,  all as one... and all made so by the  magic of a sport they all loved and  appreciated equally. And I couldn't  help ask myself a question... a long  time ago... and hundreds of times  since -- If Americans can find such  a common meeting ground in a game...  the game of baseball... If they can  play together like this... why can't  they live together like this... in  the game of life?
Over heads of Jackie and Sukeforth towards Rickey still  looking out of window. He turns back and finishes quietly
And... I know they can... and maybe  baseball can show the way... because  baseball is wholly and peculiarly  American.
He is looking at Rickey with new eyes.
That's why I called you here, Jackie.  Do you want to get in on it? Because  it starts with you!

Sukeforth looks to see what Jackie's answer will be, and  Jackie begins nodding slowly, and replies, not as if he i talking to Rickey, but as if he is asking questions of  himself... because this is serious.
If I'm strong enough. If I should be  the one on whom this all depends.
When Rickey remains silent --
I can try. For all I've got.

(simply) That should be enough. But I want  you to know exactly what you are  getting into. I'll do my part. You  mustn't let me, or all of us, down.  Jackie, we can't start you with  Brooklyn. It wouldn't be fair to  both of us. We don't know if you're  major league or not.
He nods. He agrees.

We'll let you try out for Montreal,  one of our farm teams, and later  hope you make Brooklyn. But aside  from that, if and when we announce  you for even Montreal... do you know  what's going to happen? The papers?  People? Other players? Other clubs?  The reaction in the south?
He nods.

And if we get over that and you  actually start with Montreal -- Will  you stand what you're going to have  to go through? The razzing... the  cruel, unfair razzing that every  player gets, and the special razzing,  the special name-calling you're going  to get. Can you stand it?
He nods.
Are you sure? Because... (face grim) You're not going to be able to fight  back... no matter what the offense. (emphasis) ...No matter what the offense! Do  you understand?
Both Rickey and Sukeforth wait for Jackie's reply. Finall it comes.
Can you use a ballplayer who hasn't  the spirit... to fight back?
It's a poser. He rubs his face, his chin, and practically his entire head. Eventually he finds an answer.

That's what's going to make your job  so tough. No! I want a fighter every  time. I want a man in there for  everything he's got! But... you'll  have to take it... not fight back...  and yet, do it so that somehow it's  no discredit to you... so that somehow  the crowd will sense it's not  cowardice that is stopping you but  something deeper. If, and when, you  can put that over... your troubles  are over. No player will bother you,  no man will unfairly attack you by  name or epithet, when you have  established that with the baseball  public. Because the very core of  Americans is fair play... once they  have felt the true situation involved.
Rickey stands up. Jackie follows.

Jackie, I know from your background  that you've been spiked and beaned  in baseball, you've been clipped and  two-way tackled in football, you've  been banged around on the street.  That's what you face now. And you  don't dare yell copper... or fight  back. You don't dare because more  than you... much more than just you...  hangs in the balance. (extending his hand) Take a day to think it over. And  think it over!
They shake. In the background, Sukeforth enters the scene looking a little dazed at what has happened, in fact, blo off steam.
Mrs. Robinson at table knitting as Mack enters in his str cleaning uniform, carrying lunch pail.
I'm going, Mom. See you in the  morning.
The telephone rings and Mack goes to it. Mrs. Robinson  watches.
(into phone) Hello... Yes, yes...
We hear the jangle of heavy coins coming from the receive as Mack turns to his mother in surprise.
It's Jackie, Mom. He's calling from  New York.
Also surprised, and a bit perturbed, she gets up and join Mack.
New York? What's he doin' there?
(into phone) Hello... Yeah, Jackie, it's me, Mack.  What are you...? Huh?... The  Dodgers?... The Dodgers!... Yeah...  Yeah... Yeah...
Mrs. Robinson stands quietly waiting, but we can tell she dying to know what it is all about. But Mack is listening Then he finally talks again to Jackie.

Yes, she's right here, Jackie. Just  a minute, I'll tell her. (turning to mother) Listen, Mom. Jackie's got a chance  to try out for Montreal -- baseball --  and maybe go with the Brooklyn  baseball team afterwards. He'll be  the first Negro in real baseball.  But he has to promise that no matter  what kind of trouble happens -- and  there'll be trouble --
(cutting in) Will he get hurt?

Oh, not actually... but it could be  nasty... you know. But he's got to  promise not to fight back no matter  what happens to him and he don't  know if he can trust himself to take  it. Feels he'll feel like only half  a man. And if things go wrong on his  account it might be the end of Negroes  in baseball. He doesn't know what to  do...
Mrs. Robinson reaches for the phone but Mack holds it awa and seems surprised at what appears to be a quick decisio on her part.
What are you going to tell him?
Let me have the phone, Mack.
He gives it to her. She clears her throat and then begins
Jackie...?
Jackie talking into a pay station phone.
Hello, Mom! Mack tell you? What do  you think, Mom...? (surprised) What? What? (laughing) Yeah... I feel all right. Yeah, I'm  sure. I feel swell... But what  about...?
We can't advise you, son. You have  to talk to somebody with better  judgment. Somebody in New York you  can sit down with...
But I don't know anybody in New  York...
Yes, you do, son. In Harlem there  are churches and good men at the  head of them. Find one. Tell him.  And listen. It means as much to him  as it does to you and all of us.
(thinking) Yeah... maybe you're right, Mom.  That does sound good.
...and take good care of yourself  and let us know... What?... No, we  won't tell anyone until you let us  know... Yes, just Rae. Good-bye.
She hangs up and turns from phone to Mack.
(impressed) That was good, Mom. How'd you happen  to think he could go to some church  and talk to a minister?
She sits down and takes up her knitting again.
He needed help and it just naturally  came to me he could go to church.
Jackie and an elderly minister are seated, both silent,  serious and thoughtful. Jackie seems to be waiting for an opinion from the minister. The latter finally stands up a Jackie follows suit.
(nodding) I understand. It's quite a problem. (changing tone) Do you have time for a little walk,  Mr. Robinson?
(puzzled) A walk? Well... surely, if you like.
(reaching for hat) Let's take one.

This scene, which is one of the most important in the pic will depend almost entirely on footage available, editori selection of scenes, and technical handling. We see Harle at night and get the feeling of humanity so congested, an sometimes so suppressed, that it overruns its boundaries  both physically and emotionally. Yet there is also the mu and laughter of Harlem, and the spirit of a people not to overcome. Song and violence, rowdy kids and sober elders, church and saloon, and always the streets crowded, the  buildings giving an appearance of being stuffed. Intercut these scenes are the minister and Jackie, so that they ap to be looking on and absorbing what they see. Occasionall the minister will glance at Jackie to make sure he is tak it all in. Occasionally he will explain what is going on. and the dialogue for this is to be written when the prope scenes are selected.
Jackie and the minister have arrived back at the church a stand there.
That's your people.
As Jackie nods:
I know that if you don't make good...  it may hurt us. But... (shrugging) ...we always can take hurt, if there  is the chance to benefit.
That means I take the chance.
(nodding) We all take the chance. The Lord has  appointed you one of the rising men  of your race. And we've got to be a  rising people.
The minister looks at him. Jackie nods. He keeps nodding we cut to:
A series of newspaper headlines -- front page --
Jackie Robinson sent to Montreal Royals

An announcer is standing at a mike, reading from a script holds:

When Branch Rickey announced that  Jackie Robinson had been signed and  would play for the Montreal farm  club there was plenty of excitement.  Almost everybody had something to  say about it -- and what's more --  they said it!...

A. Two men arguing on a street corner. B. Men arguing in bar. C. Man and woman arguing. D. Three Negroes discussing a serious problem. E. Group at exclusive club discussing same heatedly. F. Radio commentator talking into mike.

(continuing) ...The talk came from high places in  baseball as well -- with many a club  owner declaring that they wouldn't  stand for it. But there it was. What  would they do about it? It is  something we won't know until the  season starts in a few weeks in  Florida...
Jackie and Rae are sitting together.
(doubtfully) You're sure you want me to come to  Florida with you? I've never been  south.
(nodding) I'm sure. I'm very sure. Not afraid,  are you?... because of all this fuss  in the papers? I've never been south  either, since babyhood.
A little. But that's not why I wonder  about coming. I just don't want to  be in your way. You'll be busy with  all that spring training... people  wanting to talk to you.
(laughing softly) Who'll want to talk to me? They talk  about me... but not to me much. If  you aren't there I'll just be alone  once I'm off the field.
Is that the way you figure it?
(smiling) Why... Dem's the conditions that  prevail... like Jimmy Durante says.
(with sidelong glance) Well... if dem's the conditions,  I'll see what I can do.
We cut as Jackie, pleased, starts to put his arm around h

3. Jackie and Rae getting on train. 4. Train speeding along. (Stock) 5. Stock shot - Florida. Palm trees, stucco buildings, et 6. Shot of Jackie and Rae entering bus. Rae is about to t a seat in middle of bus when Jackie stops her and indicat she is to sit in rear of bus. 7. Rae and Jackie in bus as he points to sign near driver 8. Sign, reading: "Colored must sit in rear."
Bus coming to stop, driver opening door and passengers  beginning to exit.
Jackie stepping out and helping Rae down as a well-dresse middle-aged Negro steps up to him.
Mr. Robinson?
Yes?
(to Rae) And Mrs. Robinson?
That's right.
My name is Gaines. I am an attorney  in town. A group of us heard you  were due here for spring training.  We thought you might not have made  arrangements for a place to stay.
Why... we were going to find a  hotel...

There is no suitable hotel, Mr.  Robinson. That's why we talked it  over. I'd be pleased to have you  stop at my home while you are here  as our guests. Such as it is, it is  the only place available.
(puzzled, looking at  Rae) That's very kind of you... but...  why... we don't want to impose...
Not at all. You are a very important  man to us. It will be our pleasure,  I assure you.
Jackie studies Gaines a moment and then understands. He  extends his hand and both men shake.
(simply) Thank you.

A car pulls up outside a comfortable looking frame house. The three, Gains, Jackie and Rae, get out, the two men  dividing the bags between them, and walk towards house. A they get near the door, it opens and a dignified colored  woman steps out and smiles a welcome. From a distance we the introductions made and the group passes inside.
A general view of the training field with about fifty-odd players tossing the ball around.
We see Jackie and Gaines in car as it comes to stop near  field which forms the b.g. Jackie, carrying small zipper  bag, emerges from car, waves thanks to Gaines, and starts away.
Jackie is buttoning up his uniform and nearly a dozen  reporters, most of them white, are shooting questions at  him. Several have notebooks in their hands and are writin down his answers.
...Think you're good enough to make  the Dodgers?
Don't know if I'm good enough to  make the Montreal team -- so I'm not  even thinking about the Dodgers...
(curiously) What'll you do if a pitcher tries to  bean you?
(grins) Same as you would. Duck.
The other reporters grin.
You hope to be a Dodger sometime,  don't you?
(seriously) Sure -- provided I'm good enough...
What about the other players? You  think there'll be any trouble?
(looking up) Trouble?
(interrupting) He means -- do you expect to get  along with the other guys --- Suppose  something happens -- then what? How'll  it affect you...?
Jackie doesn't answer for a moment. Then:
(sincerely) That's too tough for me to answer.  All I can say is that I'm going to  do my best -- as a player and on and  off the field... How it'll turn out --  I don't know any more than you do...
A few start writing this down and now the trainer moves u in front of Jackie.
Sorry, boys -- but you'll have to  continue this later -- right now  Robinson's due on the field...
The reporters understand and several move to follow Jacki as he and the trainer exit.
As Jackie, the trainer, and several reporters come up out it and stand there for a moment.
Showing ballplayers, some batting, fielding, throwing bal etc. o.s., we hear the trainer's voice:
Oh, Mr. Hopper!
At the call, a tall, greying man in his fifties, in unifo turns around and walks toward Jackie and others, includin camera.
As Mr. Hopper walks into scene and up to them.
Jackie -- this is Mr. Hopper --  Manager of the Montreal Royals --  Mr. Hopper -- Jackie Robinson...
They both nod and shake hands. Hopper is a hard man to fi out. His accent is Southern -- his attitude calm and quie
Got a few minutes for us, Mr.  Hopper...?
Certainly -- but let me get Jackie  out there first...
He starts moving toward the field as he speaks and Jackie follows him. Then they both stop and look out toward the  playing field.
Almost every player on the field is looking in their  direction, curious about Jackie.
As Hopper moves forward again. Jackie is a bit nervous an we can tell that Hopper knows how he feels, but there are words.
As they move down the first base line toward a player who tossing a ball with two other men who are standing as a p some distance away.
(calling out) Boys... this is Jackie Robinson. (to Jackie) That's Harker, Billings and Piletti.  Catch with them a while.
The players and Jackie nod. Hopper turns away and Jackie  joins Harker who is the lone player, with Billings and Pi some sixty feet away.

We ANGLE SEVERAL SHOTS while the following routine takes  place. Piletti throws the ball to Harker who is alongside Jackie. Harker throws it back to Billings. Billings shoul throw now to Jackie -- instead he also throws to Harker.  They keep this up a while, with Piletti and Billings neve throwing to Jackie, just to Harker, and as it goes on and the white men realize they have committed themselves to t insult, their faces sharpen, the atmosphere becomes a lit tense as indicated by the quick glances they shoot each o and the way they avoid even looking at Jackie. It is his  first crisis, a childish one, perhaps, but nevertheless  serious. He stands quietly, his face betraying nothing, b his eyes just following the ball.
As he studies their faces, his eyes following the ball in flight. He hopes they might be kidding him.
Their faces serious. It is not a gag.
Looking out toward other players on field.
Several players, including Clay Hopper, who has turned ar are watching with interest, paying no attention to their practice.
He is troubled, not knowing what to do, but realizing tha he must do something -- yet nothing that will offend the  three players who are still ignoring him. He studies them again.
CAMERA STUDIES their faces for a brief moment. We even fe that they are sorry they have done what they have, but th don't know how to get out of it without one of them turni "chicken."
He takes a breath and moves a step closer to Harker.
Piletti throws again.
The ball is again intended for Harker but Jackie leans ov and casually gathers it in in a graceful catch. Before th can be any reaction he has the ball on its way back to  Billings.
Billings is so unnerved by the whole incident that he fum the ball and has to walk after it.
Jackie turns after throw to find Harker looking at him al gratefully. Harker nods in commendation.
Glad you did that. I don't know how  the heck we got into it.

Billings has recovered ball and is so confused by the who episode that, instead of throwing it back to Harker, who extending a glove up in the air as a sign, he throws it t Jackie instead. Harker watches and looks back at Billings Then he calls out in pretended indignation.
Oh, great! Now you're leaving me out  of it! Oh, fine!
The four of them have to laugh now and as we cut away Har is begging Jackie for the ball.
Here... let me get a chance to throw  once in a while!
His face inscrutable, he turns and studies the faces of t other ballplayers who have been watching the incident. Th too, are smiling. Thoughtfully, he walks away.
We can see two women seated on the porch.
Rae and Mrs. Gaines are talking.
You're sure you don't want to walk  into town?
(hesitantly) Well... not yet.
(pleasantly) All right. (studying Rae) You're not nervous about it, are  you? Afraid down here?

Uh... to tell you the truth, I  wouldn't be comfortable. I've never  been south and I'm afraid I wouldn't  know how to act. You probably don't  understand but... when one isn't  accustomed to... well, sort of  deferring... or whatever it is down  here... (helplessly) I'm afraid I'm not clear. Perhaps if  you explained. I worry about making  a mistake and getting Jackie into  trouble.

(gently) I understand. Of course I do. But it  really isn't as bad as reported.  Some of what you hear is true... a  lot exaggerated. We live our own  lives... and as long as we live our  own lives we are not bothered. Most  of the white people understand our  position and are helping, bit by  bit, to make things better, easier.  We've got to show respect for all of  them -- whether we respect them or  not. Always say Mister or Mrs. --  never use first names, even if they  ask you to. (she smiles) None of those are hard to do, really.  You do defer, but even that isn't  hard -- once you get used to it.
In what way?

Every way. In stores, say, don't try  to get waited on until you're the  only one left -- and give way even  if you're first and they come in  later... Never, of course, try or  expect to mix --- and as long as  they come first in everything --  you'll get along all right...
Rae is thoughtful for a moment.
Tell me -- why are you living here --  instead of up North...
To tell you the truth, I like it  down here. Even so... I like it down  here. If I left... it would be like  running away from home. I couldn't  do that.
(thoughtfully) I like it, too. It feels like home...  and yet...
And yet it's strange.
Yes. Strange. Almost... mysterious.
Mrs. Haines nods in understanding. The two sit silently a

We get a synoptic impression of activities: Jackie traini a class being instructed in base sliding, Jackie, Rae, Mr and Mrs. Gaines around a card table at home, and, at the  end, a shot showing a group of white Floridians standing silence, watching Jackie taking part in a scrub game.
Jackie emerges and Rae comes as far as screen door.
I'll be right home after practice.
Rae nods as Jackie waves and starts to run down the walk.
A car pulls up and Gaines gets out just as Jackie comes d the walk.
His face is serious as he looks towards Jackie.
As Jackie comes up to him.
Hello, Mr. Gaines. I was just on my  way to the field.
Gaines puts his hand on Jackie's shoulder.
Not this morning, Jackie.
Not this... Uh? What do you mean?
Come up on the porch. I had a call  from Mr. Rickey. I'll tell you what  he said.
Rae is still standing. Mr. Gaines offers her a chair, the nods to Jackie to take one, and seats himself.
The town has put a stop to mixed  ball playing.
(after pause) You mean... on account of me?
Yes.
Jackie looks at Rae... then back at Gaines.
Then... you mean I'm through? Is  that what he said?
By no means! Mr. Rickey isn't giving  up that easy. You're to train in  another town.
(puzzled) By myself? I don't get it.
Oh, no. With the others. Mr. Rickey's  answer to the town was to decide to  move the whole Brooklyn organization  out of here to another town. Not  far. You'll still stay here with us.
(staggered) And I... I'm the cause of all that?
(gently) Don't hold yourself cheap, Jackie.  Mr. Rickey thinks that you, and what  you stand for, is worth it.

The cynical reporter grimaces at Jackie's performance.

The other two reporters show nothing. Rickey isn't bother

As the trainer nods to Mr. Rickey and trots out on the fi As he leaves, the first reporter turns to Rickey curiousl
He ever played first?
Not that I know of...
Then why...
(interrupting) Because he's been trying so hard  he's thrown his arm out... it won't  be so hard on him at first...
The reporters think about this, but the cynic isn't impre
Just how bad is his arm, Mr. Rickey?
From what I've heard, he can't even  comb his own hair...
...and you're keeping him out  there...?
Sure.
The trainer comes back.
(to trainer) How long before his arm...?
A week will bring it around...
Rickey thinks about it, then turns to the reporters, look directly at the cynic.
I suggest that you catch our first  exhibition game -- two weeks from  today...
Here?
No -- Jacksonville...
I'll be there...
